trans-unit.source: Write data to Power BI from Apache Storm | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Write data to Power BI from Apache Storm | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Write data to Power BI from a C# topology running on an Apache Storm cluster in HDInsight. Also, create a report and real-time dashboard using Power BI.
trans-unit.target: Write data to Power BI from a C# topology running on an Apache Storm cluster in HDInsight. Also, create a report and real-time dashboard using Power BI.

trans-unit.source: The Power BI preview allows you to visually display data as reports, or dashboards.
trans-unit.target: The Power BI preview allows you to visually display data as reports, or dashboards.

trans-unit.source: Using the Power BI REST API, you can easily use data from a topology running on an Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster to Power BI.
trans-unit.target: Using the Power BI REST API, you can easily use data from a topology running on an Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster to Power BI.

trans-unit.source: In this document, you will learn how to use Power BI to create a report and dashboard from data created by a Storm topology.
trans-unit.target: In this document, you will learn how to use Power BI to create a report and dashboard from data created by a Storm topology.

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An Azure Active Directory user with <linkText>Power BI</linkText><title></title> access
trans-unit.target: An Azure Active Directory user with <linkText>Power BI</linkText><title></title> access

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio (one of the following versions)
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio (one of the following versions)

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2012 with <linkText>update 4</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2012 with <linkText>update 4</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 with <linkText>update 4</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Community</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 with <linkText>update 4</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Community</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015 <linkText>CTP6</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015 <linkText>CTP6</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio: See <linkText>Get started using the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title> for information on installation information.
trans-unit.target: The HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio: See <linkText>Get started using the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title> for information on installation information.

trans-unit.source: This example contains a C# Storm topology that randomly generates a sentence, splits the sentence into words, counts the words, and sends the word and count to the Power BI REST API.
trans-unit.target: This example contains a C# Storm topology that randomly generates a sentence, splits the sentence into words, counts the words, and sends the word and count to the Power BI REST API.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>PowerBi.Api.Client</linkText><title></title> Nuget package is used to communicate with Power BI.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>PowerBi.Api.Client</linkText><title></title> Nuget package is used to communicate with Power BI.

trans-unit.source: The following files in this project implement the Power BI specific functionality:
trans-unit.target: The following files in this project implement the Power BI specific functionality:

trans-unit.source: PowerBiBolt.cs: Implements the Storm bolt, which sends data to Power BI
trans-unit.target: PowerBiBolt.cs: Implements the Storm bolt, which sends data to Power BI

trans-unit.source: Data.cs: Describes the data object/row that will be sent to Power BI
trans-unit.target: Data.cs: Describes the data object/row that will be sent to Power BI

trans-unit.source: Power BI seems to allow the creation of multiple datasets with the same name.
trans-unit.target: Power BI seems to allow the creation of multiple datasets with the same name.

trans-unit.source: This can occur if the dataset does not exist, and your topology creates multiple instances of the Power BI Bolt.
trans-unit.target: This can occur if the dataset does not exist, and your topology creates multiple instances of the Power BI Bolt.

trans-unit.source: To avoid this, either set the parallelism hint of the bolt to 1 (as this example does,) or create the dataset before deploying the topology.
trans-unit.target: To avoid this, either set the parallelism hint of the bolt to 1 (as this example does,) or create the dataset before deploying the topology.

trans-unit.source: The CreateDataset console application included in this solution is provided as an example of how to create the dataset outside of the topology.
trans-unit.target: The CreateDataset console application included in this solution is provided as an example of how to create the dataset outside of the topology.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in the <linkText>Power BI quickstart</linkText><title></title> to sign up for Power BI.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in the <linkText>Power BI quickstart</linkText><title></title> to sign up for Power BI.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in <linkText>Register an app</linkText><title></title> to create an application registration.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in <linkText>Register an app</linkText><title></title> to create an application registration.

trans-unit.source: This will be used when accessing the Power BI REST API.
trans-unit.target: This will be used when accessing the Power BI REST API.

trans-unit.source: Save the Client ID for the application registration.
trans-unit.target: Save the Client ID for the application registration.

trans-unit.source: Download the <linkText>HDInsight C# Storm Power BI example</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Download the <linkText>HDInsight C# Storm Power BI example</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To download it, either fork/clone it using git, or use the Download link to download a .zip of the archive.
trans-unit.target: To download it, either fork/clone it using git, or use the Download link to download a .zip of the archive.

trans-unit.source: Open the sample in Visual Studio. From Solution Explorer, open the SCPHost.exe.config file, and then find the element. Enter values for the following properties of this element.
trans-unit.target: Open the sample in Visual Studio. From Solution Explorer, open the SCPHost.exe.config file, and then find the element. Enter values for the following properties of this element.

trans-unit.source: Client: The Client ID for the application registration you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Client: The Client ID for the application registration you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: User: An Azure Active Directory account that has access to Power BI.
trans-unit.target: User: An Azure Active Directory account that has access to Power BI.

trans-unit.source: Password: The password for the Azure Active Directory account.
trans-unit.target: Password: The password for the Azure Active Directory account.

trans-unit.source: (Optional).
trans-unit.target: (Optional).

trans-unit.source: The default dataset name used by this project is Words.
trans-unit.target: The default dataset name used by this project is Words.

trans-unit.source: To change this, right click on the WordCount project in Solution Explorer, select Properties, and then select Settings.
trans-unit.target: To change this, right click on the WordCount project in Solution Explorer, select Properties, and then select Settings.

trans-unit.source: Change the DatasetName entry to the desired value.
trans-unit.target: Change the DatasetName entry to the desired value.

trans-unit.source: Save and close the files.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the files.

trans-unit.source: From Solution Explorer, right-click the WordCount project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: From Solution Explorer, right-click the WordCount project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Select the HDInsight cluster from the Storm Cluster dropdown dialog.
trans-unit.target: Select the HDInsight cluster from the Storm Cluster dropdown dialog.

trans-unit.source: It may take a few seconds for the Storm Cluster dropdown to populate with server names.
trans-unit.target: It may take a few seconds for the Storm Cluster dropdown to populate with server names.

trans-unit.source: If prompted, enter the login credentials for your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If prompted, enter the login credentials for your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, log in to the one that contains your Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, log in to the one that contains your Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: When the topology has been successfully submitted, the Storm Topologies for the cluster should appear.
trans-unit.target: When the topology has been successfully submitted, the Storm Topologies for the cluster should appear.

trans-unit.source: Select the WordCount topology from the list to view information about the running topology.
trans-unit.target: Select the WordCount topology from the list to view information about the running topology.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The topologies, with the WordCount topology selected</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The topologies, with the WordCount topology selected</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can also view Storm Topologies from Server Explorer: Expand Azure, HDInsight, right-click a Storm on HDInsight cluster, and then select View Storm Topologies.
trans-unit.target: You can also view Storm Topologies from Server Explorer: Expand Azure, HDInsight, right-click a Storm on HDInsight cluster, and then select View Storm Topologies.

trans-unit.source: When viewing the Topology Summary, scroll until you see the Bolts section.
trans-unit.target: When viewing the Topology Summary, scroll until you see the Bolts section.

trans-unit.source: In this section, note the Executed column for the PowerBI bolt.
trans-unit.target: In this section, note the Executed column for the PowerBI bolt.

trans-unit.source: Use the refresh button at the top of the page to refresh until the value changes to something other than zero.
trans-unit.target: Use the refresh button at the top of the page to refresh until the value changes to something other than zero.

trans-unit.source: When this number starts to increase, it indicates that items are being written to Power BI.
trans-unit.target: When this number starts to increase, it indicates that items are being written to Power BI.

trans-unit.source: In a browser, visit <linkText>https://PowerBI.com</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In a browser, visit <linkText>https://PowerBI.com</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Sign in with your account.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with your account.

trans-unit.source: On the left side of the page, expand Datasets.
trans-unit.target: On the left side of the page, expand Datasets.

trans-unit.source: Select the Words entry.
trans-unit.target: Select the Words entry.

trans-unit.source: This is the dataset created by the example topology.
trans-unit.target: This is the dataset created by the example topology.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Words dataset entry</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Words dataset entry</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the Fields area, expand WordCount.
trans-unit.target: From the Fields area, expand WordCount.

trans-unit.source: Drag the Count and Word entries to the middle part of the page.
trans-unit.target: Drag the Count and Word entries to the middle part of the page.

trans-unit.source: This will create a new chart that displays a bar for each word indicating how many times the word has occurred.
trans-unit.target: This will create a new chart that displays a bar for each word indicating how many times the word has occurred.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>WordCount chart</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>WordCount chart</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the upper left of the page, select Save to create a new report.
trans-unit.target: From the upper left of the page, select Save to create a new report.

trans-unit.source: Enter Word Count as the name of the Report.
trans-unit.target: Enter Word Count as the name of the Report.

trans-unit.source: Select the Power BI logo to return to the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Select the Power BI logo to return to the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Word Count report now appears under Reports.
trans-unit.target: The Word Count report now appears under Reports.

trans-unit.source: Beside Dashboard, select the + icon to create a new dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Beside Dashboard, select the + icon to create a new dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Name the new dashboard Live Word Count.
trans-unit.target: Name the new dashboard Live Word Count.

trans-unit.source: Select the Word Count report you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Select the Word Count report you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: When displayed, select the chart, then select the pushpin icon to the upper right of the chart.
trans-unit.target: When displayed, select the chart, then select the pushpin icon to the upper right of the chart.

trans-unit.source: You should receive a notification that it was pinned to the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: You should receive a notification that it was pinned to the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>chart with pushpin displayed</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>chart with pushpin displayed</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Power BI logo to return to the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Select the Power BI logo to return to the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Select the Live Word Count dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Select the Live Word Count dashboard.

trans-unit.source: It now contains the Word Count chart, and the chart updates as new entries are sent to Power BI from the WordCount topology running on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: It now contains the Word Count chart, and the chart updates as new entries are sent to Power BI from the WordCount topology running on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The live dashboard</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The live dashboard</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The topology will continue to run until you stop it or delete the Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: The topology will continue to run until you stop it or delete the Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to stop the topology.
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to stop the topology.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the Topology Summary window for the WordCount topology.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the Topology Summary window for the WordCount topology.

trans-unit.source: If the Topology Summary is not already open, go to Server Explorer, expand the Azure and HDInsight entries, right-click on the Storm on HDInsight cluster and select View Storm Topologies.
trans-unit.target: If the Topology Summary is not already open, go to Server Explorer, expand the Azure and HDInsight entries, right-click on the Storm on HDInsight cluster and select View Storm Topologies.

trans-unit.source: Finally, select the WordCount topology.
trans-unit.target: Finally, select the WordCount topology.

trans-unit.source: Select the Kill button to stop the WordCount topology.
trans-unit.target: Select the Kill button to stop the WordCount topology.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Kill button on the toplogy summary</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Kill button on the toplogy summary</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this document, you learned how to send data from a Storm topology to Power BI using REST.
trans-unit.target: In this document, you learned how to send data from a Storm topology to Power BI using REST.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to work with other Azure technologies, see the following:
trans-unit.target: For information on how to work with other Azure technologies, see the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title>
